description:
'''Lucero Hogaza León{{efn|Pronounced {{IPA|es|luˈseɾo}}}}''' (born 29 August 1969) is a Mexican singer, actress, and television personality. Dubbed the "[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|Americas' Girlfriend]]", she is known for her influence in [[Latin music]] and Hispanic television, with a career spanning over four decades. At age 10, Lucero began her career as a [[child actress]] in 1980, gaining early fame through [[Televisa]]'s [[Children's television shows|children’s television shows]], including ''[[Alegrías De Mediodía|Alegrías de Mediodía]]'', ''[[Chiquilladas]]'', and her debut starring role in ''[[Chispita (TV series)|Chispita]]''. She made her musical debut in 1982 with ''[[Él (album)|Él]]'', and by the late 1980s, she had emerged as one of the most prominent [[teen idol]] singers of her generation, releasing [[teen pop]] albums such as ''[[Un Pedacito de Mí]]'' (1986), ''[[Ocho Quince]]'' (1988), and ''[[Cuéntame (Lucerito album)|Cuéntame]]'' (1989).

During the 1990s, Lucero starred the [[Telenovela|telenovelas]] ''[[Cuando llega el amor|Cuando Llega el Amor]]'' (1990), ''[[Los Parientes Pobres]]'' (1993), and ''[[Lazos de Amor]]'' (1996), establishing herself as a major figure in the genre. At the same time, she continued her music career with [[Latin pop]] albums such as ''[[Sólo Pienso en Ti (Lucero album)|Sólo Pienso en Ti]]'' (1990), ''[[Lucero (album)|Lucero]]'' (1993), ''[[Siempre Contigo (Lucero album)|Siempre Contigo]]'' (1994), and ''[[Piel de Ángel]]'' (1997). She also ventured into [[ranchera]] music with the albums ''[[Con Mi Sentimiento]]'' (1990), ''[[Lucero de México]]'' (1992), ''[[Cariño de Mis Cariños]]'' (1994), and ''[[Cerca de ti (Lucero album)|Cerca de Ti]]'' (1998). She voiced [[Jane Porter (Tarzan)|Jane]] in the [[Spanish language in the Americas|Latin Spanish]] version of ''[[Tarzan (1999 film)|Tarzan]]'' (1999) and sang the Latin Spanish version of "[[Reflection (song)|Reflection]]," for ''[[Mulan (1998 film)|Mulan]]'' (1998). From 1997 to 2004, she also hosted the annual broadcasts of ''[[Teletón (Mexico)|Teletón México]]''.

During the 21st century, Lucero released the albums ''[[Mi destino|Mi Destino]]'' (2000), ''[[Un Nuevo Amor (Lucero album)|Un Nuevo Amor]]'' (2002), and ''[[Quiéreme Tal Como Soy]]'' (2006) to varying critical and commercial success. On television, she starred in hit telenovelas including ''[[Mi Destino Eres Tú]]'' (2000), ''[[Alborada (TV series)|Alborada]]'' (2005), ''[[Mañana es para siempre|Mañana es Para Siempre]]'' (2007), ''[[Soy tu dueña|Soy tu Dueña]]'' (2010), and ''[[Por ella soy Eva|Por Ella Soy Eva]]'' (2012). She also hosted the [[Latin Grammy Awards]] from 2006 to 2013 (except in 2008), as well as the first two editions of the [[Latin American Music Awards]]. In addition, she served as a coach on the first season of ''[[La Voz (Mexican TV series)|La Voz]]'' in 2011.

Lucero is one of the [[List of best-selling Latin music artists|best-selling Latin music artists]], with estimated global sales of over 16 million records. Her accolades include a [[Billboard Latin Music Awards|''Billboard'' Latin Music Award]], five [[El Heraldo de México Awards]], two [[Lo Nuestro Awards]], and 21 [[Premios TVyNovelas]] (the most of any artist). In recognition of her impact on Hispanic television, she has also received the 'Leaders in Spanish-language [[Emmy Awards|Emmy Award]]' and an Outstanding Achievement Award from the [[Hispanic Television Summit]]. In 2025, [[Billboard (magazine)|''Billboard'']] named her among the best female Latin pop artists of all time.
